metadata.case_name: Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited v. Respondent

facts.text: On or about April 15, 1908, the Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay auctioned plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 of new survey Nos. 8234, 8235 and 8244 situate in the Princess Street Estate containing an area of 2235 square yards.
Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder, declared tenant at annual rent per square yard calculated at 4.5% of Rs. 29, signed memorandum of agreement, deposited moneys, entered possession.
By clause 7, Sitaram agreed to build and complete within specified time a building consisting of 5 floors costing not less than Rs. 50,000 according to approved plans.
Clause 17 required insurance of buildings upon roofing in.
Clause 18 provided for grant of 999-year lease from April 15, 1908, upon completion certification.
Clause 25 allowed forfeiture if buildings not completed.
Sitaram erected New Sitaram Building on the plots.

On April 19, 1916, Indenture of lease between Trustees and Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna (receiver of Sitaram in Suit No. 720 of 1913) demised the land and buildings for 999 years from April 15, 1908, at specified rent, with covenants including user restrictions, repairs, insurance, re-entry proviso.
In 1925, properties of Trustees vested in Bombay Municipality under Bombay Act XVI of 1925.
By deed of assignment dated April 26, 1948, Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited (appellant, registered under Bombay Co-operative Societies Act VII of 1921) acquired lessee's interest.
On June 29, 1948, appellant served notice on respondent (monthly tenant of Block No. B/2 ground floor at Rs. 52-5-9 rent) to quit and vacate by July 31, 1948.
Respondent replied claiming protection under Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Act LVII of 1947).
Respondent did not vacate; appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 in Bombay City Civil Court for possession and mesne profits from August 1, 1948, claiming Act LVII of 1947 did not apply.
Respondent's written statement: Court lacked jurisdiction under section 28; entitled to Act protection; building constructed at lessee's expense; premises not belonging to Government/local authority.
City Civil Court decreed for appellant on January 24, 1949.
Respondent appealed: First Appeal No. 456 of 1949; High Court (Weston and Shah JJ.) reversed on December 2, 1949, holding Act applied, no jurisdiction, return plaint.
High Court declined leave; appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 applies to the demised premises which originally belonged to the Board of Trustees (now vested in Bombay Municipality, a local authority).
Whether the City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit, given section 28 of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Demised premises belonged to Trustees for Improvement of City of Bombay (local authority), now Bombay Municipality (local authority); section 4(1) exempts premises belonging to local authority.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Rents Act LVII of 1947, section 4(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Immunity attaches to premises itself, available to lessee and sub-tenants; protects interests of local authority in building leases.

respondent_arguments.text: Act applies; premises/building belong in substance to lessee (erected at lessee's cost, 999-year lease, subletting rights); City Civil Court lacks jurisdiction under section 28.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Rents Act LVII of 1947, sections 4(1), 28; section 15

respondent_arguments.text: Section 4(1) first part exempts only landlord-tenant where local authority is landlord; immunity not for sub-tenants.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(1) construction; preamble (rent control between landlord-tenant)

court_reasoning.text: Civil Court has inherent jurisdiction to decide its own jurisdiction; preliminary objection rejected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If Act does not apply, section 28 not invocable.

court_reasoning.text: Section 4(1) has three parts; first part exempts 'premises belonging to Government or local authority' absolutely, not limited to landlord-tenant relation as in second part.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature used different phrasing deliberately; immunity attaches to premises.

court_reasoning.text: Premises include land and building; building belongs to lessor despite lessee erection, per lease terms, covenants showing lessor ownership/control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Belonging to' in ordinary sense; no transfer of ownership in lease (TP Act s.105).

court_reasoning.text: Immunity protects local authority interests in development via building leases; extends to lessees/sub-lessees; otherwise illusory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Frustrates purpose if limited to direct landlord.

holdings.text: Demised premises belong to local authority (Bombay Municipality); Bombay Rents Act LVII of 1947 does not apply.

precedents_cited.relevance: Immunity to premises of local authority increases reversion value.
Approved Clark v. Downes on immunity.
'Property' and 'belonging to' are convertible terms in ordinary signification.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 4(1) exempts premises belonging to local authority; s.28 bars jurisdiction if Act applies; s.15 restricts subletting.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Lease transfers right to enjoy, not ownership; fixtures per agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act XVI of 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of Trustees' properties in Bombay Municipality.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored City Civil Court decree for possession and mesne profits, holding Bombay Rents Act 1947 inapplicable to premises belonging to local authority.
outcome.relief_granted: Vacant possession of Block No. B/2 and mesne profits from August 1, 1948.

key_quotes.text: This Act shall not apply to any premises belonging to the Government or a local authority...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The conclusion is, therefore, irresistible that the Legislature did not by the first part intend to exempt the relationship of landlord and tenant but intended to confer on the premises belonging to Government an immunity from the operation of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: A man's property is that which is his own, that which belongs to him.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Ordinary meaning of 'belonging to' from precedent.
